Doc 5(Title: "How 40 years ago ‘The Wiz’ forever changed black culture ...") By Gerrick D. Kennedy / Los Angeles Times Forty years after its original release, no film has uniquely defined black culture and shaped the framework of a musical genre quite like “The Wiz.”
An adaptation of the groundbreaking Broadway musical — itself a retelling of L. Frank Baum’s classic 1900 children’s fantasy “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz” that became the beloved Judy Garland movie — the Sidney Lumet-directed film had a rapturous soundtrack produced by Quincy Jones, a cast that included Diana Ross, Michael Jackson, Lena Horne, Nipsey Russell, Mabel King and Richard Pryor and an aesthetic firmly rooted in black culture.
For a generation of black Americans, this was the first time they saw people who spoke, sung and moved the way they did in a Broadway production and, later, a big-screen musical, and it has become a kind of rite of passage for the black community.
Everyone remembers their first time experiencing “The Wiz.” If it’s the stage production, that likely came from performing it in high school or seeing a touring troupe tackle it, but the film is the most accessible entry into the all-black retelling of “The Wizard of Oz.” Many of us recall watching it with family during the holidays, huddled around the TV singing the tunes.
What was revolutionary about it, first in the original Broadway production and then amplified by Jones’ work on the splashy film version, was its songbook.
“Grease” had arrived to big screens months earlier, as did “Thank God It’s Friday” (which, like “The Wiz,” was a Motown production), but both pulled from the world of disco and were tailored toward white audiences.
“The Wiz,” however, weaved together gospel, blues, soul and R&B — genres that are unequivocally black creations — and were narratives of the black experience, an especially bold move given Hollywood’s monochromatic palette.
It bombed upon its release on Oct. 24, 1978 (it cost more than it earned, and critics dismissed it as a saccharine imitation of its stage predecessor), but that didn’t matter to audience members who were seeing themselves reflected on screen in ways they hadn’t before.
How it all started
To understand its power, let’s rewind to 1972. It was then that New York disc jockey Ken Harper, inspired by the dominance of the Motown sound, imagined a take of Baum’s epic fantasy that distilled the tale through a black lens.
He got the backing of Fox — in exchange for first option for film rights, publishing rights and album rights — and in 1974 “The Wiz: The Super Soul Musical ‘Wonderful Wizard of Oz’ ” opened in Baltimore, before hitting Broadway the following year.
“The Wiz” weathered a ballooning budget, mixed reviews, technical hiccups, sluggish ticket sales and the constant threat of closure to become a sensation that earned seven Tony Awards, including best musical, and a multimillion-dollar adaptation from Motown and Universal, who grabbed the rights from Fox.
Both the stage and film productions of “The Wiz” have a common theme: the perseverance of the black American dream despite mighty odds. But where the original stage production uses Dorothy’s journey home from the Land of Oz to explore slavery, emancipation, the great migration and faith, the film updates it to a post-civil rights era.
Rural, turn-of-the-century Kansas in Baum’s version became contemporary Harlem. Now our heroine is an introverted Harlem schoolteacher that has never been south of 125th Street. Emerald City is a slick urban core brimming with temptations, and the Winkies are, in effect, the poor working class stuck under the thumb of a slave-driving tyrant.
“The Wiz” is foremost a story of racial liberation, and an early piece of Afro-futurism — the combination of science fiction, fantasy, magic realism and ancient African tradition that critiques historical events or envisions a black future, inspiring such recent groundbreaking films as “Get Out” and “Black Panther” — but what has cemented its cult status is the music and movement seen onscreen.

urbanization, the process by which large numbers of people become permanently concentrated in relatively small areas, forming cities.
The definition of what constitutes a city changes from time to time and place to place, but it is most usual to explain the term as a matter of demographics. The United Nations does not have its own definition of “urban” but instead follows the definitions used in each country, which may vary considerably. The United States, for instance, uses “urban place” to mean any locality where more than 2,500 people live. In Peru the term is applied to population centres with 100 or more dwellings.
History
Whatever the numerical definition, it is clear that the course of human history has been marked by a process of accelerated urbanization. It was not until the Neolithic Period, beginning at roughly 10,000 bce, that humans were able to form small permanent settlements. Cities of more than 100,000 did not exist until the time of Classical antiquity, and even those did not become common until the sustained population explosion of the last three centuries. In 1800 less than 3 percent of the world’s population was living in cities of 20,000 or more; this had increased to about one-quarter of the population by the mid-1960s. By the early 21st century more than half of the world’s population resided in urban centres.
The little towns of ancient civilizations, both in the Old World and the New, were only possible because of improvements in agriculture and transportation. As farming became more productive, it produced a surplus of food. The development of means of transportation, dating from the invention of the wheel about 3500 bce, made it possible for the surplus from the countryside to feed urban populations, a system that continues to the present day.
Despite the small size of these villages, the people in early towns lived quite close together. Distances could be no greater than an easy walk, and nobody could live out of the range of the water supply. In addition, because cities were constantly subject to attack, they were quite often walled, and it was difficult to extend barricades over a large area. Archaeological excavations have suggested that the population density in the cities of 2000 bce may have been as much as 128,000 per square mile (49,400 per square km). By contrast, the present cities of Kolkata and Shanghai, with densities of more than 70,000 per square mile, are regarded as extremes of overcrowding.
With few exceptions, the elite—aristocrats, government officials, clergy, and the wealthy—lived in the centre of ancient cities, which was usually located near the most important temple. Farther out were the poor, who were sometimes displaced beyond the city walls altogether.
The greatest city of antiquity was Rome, which at its height in the 3rd century ce covered almost 4 square miles (10 square km) and had at least 800,000 inhabitants. To provide for this enormous population, the empire constructed a system of aqueducts that channeled drinking water from hills as far away as 44 miles (70 km). Inside the city itself, the water was pumped to individual homes through a remarkable network of conduits and lead pipes, the equal of which was not seen until the 20th century. As in most early cities, Roman housing was initially built from dried clay molded about wooden frameworks. As the city grew, it began to include structures made from mud, brick, concrete, and, eventually, finely carved marble.

question: how can we stop animal extinction
agent_answer:
<answer> Stopping animal extinction requires a multi-faceted approach that addresses various factors contributing to species decline. Conservation efforts can be broadly categorized into protecting habitats, reducing human-wildlife conflict, combating poaching, and improving breeding programs. 

To protect habitats, it is crucial to establish and expand protected areas such as national parks and wildlife reserves. These areas provide safe havens for wildlife and help maintain biodiversity. However, simply setting up these areas is not enough; they must be effectively managed to ensure species survival.

Reducing human-wildlife conflict is another key strategy. This involves minimizing interactions between humans and animals that can lead to harm on either side. For instance, implementing better land-use planning to avoid encroachment into natural habitats can reduce conflicts. Additionally, providing compensation to farmers who suffer losses due to wildlife can encourage coexistence.

Combating poaching is essential for endangered species. Strengthening law enforcement and international cooperation to combat illegal wildlife trade is vital. This includes increasing penalties for poachers and traffickers, enhancing surveillance, and using technology such as drones and satellite tracking to monitor wildlife.

Improving breeding programs can help recover populations of endangered species. Captive breeding programs can play a role in boosting numbers, but successful reintroduction back into the wild is also critical. These programs need to be carefully planned and monitored to ensure genetic diversity and fitness of the released individuals.

Furthermore, addressing climate change, which is a significant threat to many species, is crucial. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions, promoting sustainable practices, and supporting climate-resilient conservation strategies can help mitigate the impacts of global warming on ecosystems.

Public awareness and education are also important. Raising awareness about the importance of biodiversity and the consequences of species loss can inspire action at both individual and community levels. Community-based conservation initiatives that involve local stakeholders can be particularly effective.

In summary, stopping animal extinction requires a combination of habitat protection, conflict resolution, anti-poaching measures, breeding programs, climate action, and public engagement. Each of these approaches plays a critical role in safeguarding wildlife and preserving our planet's biodiversity. </answer>

question: what are some ways in which governments address economic and social inequality?
agent_answer:
<answer> Governments address economic and social inequality through various policies and programs aimed at promoting fairness and reducing disparities. These approaches can be broadly categorized into direct interventions and structural reforms.

Direct interventions often involve redistributive measures such as progressive taxation, where higher-income individuals pay a larger percentage of their income in taxes, which can then be used to fund social services and support lower-income groups. Additionally, governments may provide direct financial assistance through cash transfers, subsidies, or welfare programs to help low-income families meet basic needs and improve their economic situation.

Structural reforms aim to create more equitable opportunities and conditions for all citizens. This includes investing in education and healthcare, which can improve long-term outcomes for individuals and society as a whole. By ensuring access to quality education and healthcare, governments can help break cycles of poverty and promote upward mobility. 

Another key approach is labor market regulation, such as minimum wage laws, anti-discrimination policies, and worker protection measures, which can help ensure fair compensation and working conditions. Universal access to affordable housing is also crucial, as stable and secure housing is essential for both economic stability and well-being.

Social safety nets, including unemployment benefits and support for vulnerable populations like the elderly or disabled, are important components of addressing inequality. These programs provide a buffer against economic shocks and help maintain social cohesion.

Finally, governments can promote economic growth through investment in infrastructure, technology, and innovation, which can create jobs and stimulate economic activity. However, it's important that these benefits are widely shared, rather than concentrated among a small elite.

While these strategies can be effective, they often face challenges such as political resistance, implementation difficulties, and the need for sustained commitment over time. The success of these efforts can vary significantly depending on the specific context and resources available to each government.</answer>

question: what colleges look for in students
agent_answer:
Based on the information provided, colleges generally look for a combination of academic achievement, extracurricular involvement, and personal qualities in their applicants. Here's a breakdown:

1. **Academic Performance**:
   - Grades in college-prep courses and a challenging curriculum are highly valued. Colleges want to see that students are challenging themselves academically.
   - Standardized test scores, such as the SAT or ACT, are considered important by many colleges, though some have become test-optional.
   - Class rank is less important now compared to the past, but it can still be relevant in certain contexts.

2. **Extracurricular Activities**:
   - Deep and sustained involvement in a few activities, demonstrating leadership and passion, is preferred over a broad list of superficial engagements.
   - Participation in clubs, sports, volunteer work, and other activities can show a well-rounded individual and potential contributions to the campus community.

3. **Personal Qualities**:
   - Personal qualities such as curiosity, creativity, and social consciousness are sought after by many colleges. These qualities are often reflected in the applicant's essay and letters of recommendation.
   - Demonstrated interest in the college, such as visiting the campus or engaging with the institution online, can positively impact the application.

4. **Recommendations and Essays**:
   - Strong recommendations from teachers and counselors can highlight a student's strengths and potential.
   - Well-crafted essays that showcase the applicant's personality and unique experiences can differentiate them from other candidates.

5. **Character and Values**:
   - Colleges value applicants who exhibit character and values that align with the institution's mission and vision. This can include integrity, kindness, and a commitment to diversity and inclusion.

In summary, colleges look for a holistic profile that includes academic excellence, extracurricular depth, and personal qualities that demonstrate a fit with the institution. Each college may prioritize these factors differently, so it's essential for students to research and tailor their applications to the specific needs and values of each college.
</answer>

question: how can a manager determine whether his or her firm needs improvement in control?
agent_answer:
From the information provided, here are key points for a manager to determine whether their firm needs improvement in control:

1. **Poor Financial Performance**: A decline in financial metrics could indicate issues with financial control. The manager should review financial reports and compare them with industry standards.

2. **Internal Crises**: Events like strikes, natural disasters, or significant changes in the workforce can disrupt operations and highlight gaps in control systems.

3. **Employee Expectations**: As employee expectations evolve, the manager should assess if current control mechanisms still meet the needs of the workforce. This includes evaluating benefits, work-life balance, and job satisfaction.

4. **Operational Issues**: Regularly reviewing operational processes can reveal inefficiencies or areas where controls are lacking. This might involve conducting process audits or seeking feedback from employees.

5. **Strategic Alignment**: Ensuring that control measures align with the company's strategic goals is crucial. Misalignment can lead to ineffective resource allocation and poor performance.

6. **Compliance and Legal Requirements**: Regularly checking compliance with laws and regulations can prevent legal issues and ensure that the firm is operating ethically.

7. **Customer Feedback**: Gathering and analyzing customer feedback can provide insights into service quality and areas where control over service delivery might need improvement.

To improve specific types of control, a manager can:
- **Operations Control**: Implement lean manufacturing techniques or Six Sigma methodologies to streamline processes.
- **Financial Control**: Strengthen budgeting and forecasting processes, and implement internal audit procedures.
- **Structural Control**: Review organizational charts and roles to ensure clarity and accountability.
- **Strategic Control**: Develop and monitor key performance indicators (KPIs) aligned with strategic objectives.

By systematically addressing these areas, a manager can enhance overall control within their firm.

1. **Poor Financial Performance**: A decline in financial metrics could indicate issues with financial control. The manager should review financial reports and compare them with industry standards.

2. **Internal Crises**: Events like strikes, natural disasters, or significant changes in the workforce can disrupt operations and highlight gaps in control systems.

3. **Employee Expectations**: As employee expectations evolve, the manager should assess if current control mechanisms still meet the needs of the workforce. This includes evaluating benefits, work-life balance, and job satisfaction.

- **Strategic Control**: Develop and monitor key performance indicators (KPIs) aligned with strategic objectives.

Doc 3(Title: "Capitalist Economic System - Economics Help") A capitalist economic system is one characterised by free markets and the absence of government intervention in the economy.
In practice a capitalist economy will need some government intervention, primarily to protect private property. (This is important to distinguish capitalism from anarchism, where there is absolutely no government present)
Features of a capitalist economic system
- Economic freedom. Individuals free to set up business and provide the goods and services they want.
- Consumer sovereignty. Consumers free to decide which goods and services to purchase.
- Limited government. Government intervention limited to the protection of private property and provision of public goods.
- Finance sector. Capitalism requires a developed banking and financial system which can provide loans to companies and banking services to households.
- Profit motive is seen as important for enabling an efficient distribution of resources and encouraging innovation and responsive markets.
- Market forces. Goods and services are distributed according to ‘the invisible hand of the market’ – in other words, the allocation of goods is determined by market forces. For example, if demand rises, firms have an incentive to increase supply.
- Flexible labour markets – easy to hire and fire workers.
- Free trade. Low tariff barriers to encourage international trade.
Friedman on Capitalism
“There is one and only one social responsibility of business – to use it resources and engage in activities designed to increase its profits so long as it stays within the rules of the game, which is to say, engages in open and free competition without deception or fraud”
― Milton Friedman, Capitalism and Freedom (1962)
Examples of capitalist economies

- Hong Kong
- Singapore
- New Zealand
- Australia
- Canada
In the real world, many economies which are viewed to have a capitalist economic system may have government spending taking up to 35% of GDP. This is because the government pays for welfare, health, education and national defence. However, the economy is still viewed as capitalist because in the area of private enterprise, firms are free to decide what to produce and for whom.
Economists who advocate capitalism
- Friedrich Hayek – The Road to Serfdom (1944)
- Milton Friedman – Capitalism and Freedom (1962)
- Adam Smith – The Wealth of Nations (1776)
Alternatives to capitalism
A capitalist economic system is often contrasted to a socialist or communist economic system where economic decisions are made centrally by government agencies. In a communist economy, the means of production are owned collectively and the government has more say in what to produce, how to produce and how to distribute resources.
Advantage and disadvantages of capitalism
Advantages of a capitalist economic system
- More efficient
- Less bureaucratic
- More innovation
- Discourages discrimination and forces people to trade with each other – breaking down barriers.
Problems of a capitalist economic system
- Inequality. Capitalist economic systems invariably lead to inequalities of wealth and income. However, it is argued that this inequality provides an incentive for wealth generation and economic growth.
- Monopoly. In a capitalist society, firms could gain monopoly power over consumers and workers.
- Environmental problems. A capitalist society driven by the profit motive may take decisions to maximise economic income in the short term but at a cost of environmental problems in the long-term.
Different types of Capitalism
- Turbo-capitalism – free-market capitalism with little government regulation
- Responsible capitalism – Free markets but also a social welfare net. More reflective of European economies with private markets, but strong government intervention

Capitalism works well because of the way it deals with self-interest, distributes limited resources, grows standards of living, and provides incentives for excellence. We will discuss these four concepts in detail:
Self-Interest
"It is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer or the baker that we expect our dinner, but from their regard to their own interests." -Adam Smith
The prevailing interest among humans in this world is self-interest. Anti-capitalists call it greed. Religion calls it sin. Science calls it survival. In fact, few philosophies refer to self interest in itself as something good, but it is inescapable. You cannot educate people out of self-interest. It is the natural order of human behavior and the only way to tame this beast is to work with it. Dr. Walter E. Williams describes how capitalism works with self-interest:
"Capitalism is relatively new in human history. Prior to capitalism, the way people amassed great wealth was by looting, plundering and enslaving their fellow man. Capitalism made it possible to become wealthy by serving your fellow man." 2
Don't take this as an argument that capitalism is perfect or produces perfect results. Far from it. However, capitalism is the closest thing to a perfect economic system we will ever see on this earth.
Limited Resources
There are a limited number of resources in the world. Therefore, a system is needed that rations out these resources in a manner that benefits all the stakeholders. As we discussed in Gas Shortages previously, prices determined through supply and demand allow resources to be allocated to those who need them most. In the case of a crisis, the person with an empty tank of gas can buy what he currently needs most (because the price will be high enough to deter people who don't really need it).
Standard of Living
While political rhetoric often describes dire economic conditions and the woes of class separation, the truth is, people have access to more products and services than ever before. There are many ways to gauge the current standard of living, but let's discuss a few related to "the poor". Robert Rector of the Heritage Foundation3 wrote using 1990 census data:
- 38 percent of the persons whom the Census Bureau identifies as "poor" own their own homes with a median value of $39,200.
- 62 percent of "poor" households own a car; 14 percent own two or more cars.
- Nearly half of all "poor" households have air-conditioning; 31 percent have microwave ovens.
- Nationwide, some 22,000 "poor" households have heated swimming pools or Jacuzzis.
Excellence
Capitalism is the only economic system in the world that promotes voluntary excellence in individuals. Individuals are rewarded based on the amount of value they provide to the market. Capitalism provides incentives to be great and invent things that were never thought possible. It is a system that promotes growth among individuals and society as a whole.
While it would be impossible here to fully explain all the reasons why capitalism is the best economic system in this post, there are many books devoted to this endeavor. Some of these books include:
- Capitalism and Freedom by Milton Friedman
- The Wealth of Nations by Adam Smith
- Free to Choose by Milton Friedman and Rose Friedman
- The Politically Incorrect Guide to Capitalism by Robert Murphy
- Freedomnomics by John Lott

"Capitalism is relatively new in human history. Prior to capitalism, the way people amassed great wealth was by looting, plundering and enslaving their fellow man. Capitalism made it possible to become wealthy by serving your fellow man." 2
Don't take this as an argument that capitalism is perfect or produces perfect results. Far from it. However, capitalism is the closest thing to a perfect economic system we will ever see on this earth.
Limited Resources
There are a limited number of resources in the world. Therefore, a system is needed that rations out these resources in a manner that benefits all the stakeholders. As we discussed in Gas Shortages previously, prices determined through supply and demand allow resources to be allocated to those who need them most. In the case of a crisis, the person with an empty tank of gas can buy what he currently needs most (because the price will be high enough to deter people who don't really need it).
Standard of Living
While political rhetoric often describes dire economic conditions and the woes of class separation, the truth is, people have access to more products and services than ever before. There are many ways to gauge the current standard of living, but let's discuss a few related to "the poor". Robert Rector of the Heritage Foundation3 wrote using 1990 census data:
- 38 percent of the persons whom the Census Bureau identifies as "poor" own their own homes with a median value of $39,200.

Excellence
Capitalism is the only economic system in the world that promotes voluntary excellence in individuals. Individuals are rewarded based on the amount of value they provide to the market. Capitalism provides incentives to be great and invent things that were never thought possible. It is a system that promotes growth among individuals and society as a whole.

question: how has law changed over time
agent_answer:
<answer> Law has evolved significantly over time, reflecting changes in society, technology, and human understanding. The fundamental principles of justice, fairness, and order have remained constant, but the specific rules and methods used to achieve these goals have changed dramatically.

In ancient societies, laws were often based on religious texts, customs, or the decisions of rulers. For example, Roman law, which emerged around 600 BCE, was heavily influenced by the Code of Hammurabi and later codified in the Twelve Tables. These early legal systems laid the groundwork for modern legal concepts such as contracts and property rights.

The Enlightenment period (17th-18th centuries) brought significant changes to legal thought. Philosophers like John Locke and Montesquieu emphasized individual rights, the rule of law, and separation of powers. This led to the development of constitutions that enshrined basic freedoms and established checks on governmental power. The U.S. Constitution, written in 1787, is a prime example of this new approach to governance.

In the 20th century, the rise of industrialization and globalization brought about new legal challenges. International laws and organizations, such as the United Nations, were established to address global issues like trade, human rights, and conflict resolution. Environmental laws also began to emerge as concerns about pollution and conservation grew.

Technological advancements have further transformed the legal landscape. Intellectual property laws now protect digital content, while data privacy laws are designed to safeguard personal information in an era of widespread online communication. Cybersecurity regulations aim to protect against cyber threats.

Moreover, the interpretation and application of laws continue to evolve. Legal realism, a school of thought that emphasizes the practical aspects of law, has influenced how judges and lawmakers approach legal issues. Additionally, social movements and changing societal values have led to shifts in areas like civil rights, LGBTQ+ rights, and reproductive rights.

While the general principles of law remain important, the specifics and scope of legal systems are constantly adapting to meet the needs of evolving societies. </answer>

question: why do scientists accept the big bang theory
agent_answer:
<answer> Scientists accept the Big Bang theory because it is the most well-supported and comprehensive explanation for the origin and evolution of the universe based on current scientific evidence and observations. The theory is supported by multiple lines of evidence, including:

1. **Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB):** The CMB is the thermal radiation left over from the early stages of the universe. Its uniformity and slight temperature fluctuations align with predictions made by the Big Bang theory.
2. **Hubble's Law:** Observations show that galaxies are moving away from each other at speeds proportional to their distance, indicating an expanding universe. This expansion is a key prediction of the Big Bang model.
3. **Abundance of Light Elements:** The relative abundance of hydrogen, helium, and lithium in the universe can be accurately predicted by the Big Bang nucleosynthesis model, supporting the theory's description of early cosmic conditions.
4. **Large-Scale Structure Formation:** Simulations based on the Big Bang theory predict the formation of large-scale structures such as galaxy clusters and superclusters, which match observational data.

While the Big Bang theory is widely accepted, it is not without its challenges and areas of ongoing research. For instance, the singularity problem at the beginning of the universe and the mystery of dark matter and dark energy remain unsolved. However, these issues do not invalidate the overall framework of the Big Bang theory but rather highlight the need for further investigation into the fundamental nature of the cosmos.</answer>

question: why doping in sports is bad
agent_answer:
<answer> Doping in sports is considered bad for several reasons. First, it gives unfair advantages to athletes who use performance-enhancing drugs (PEDs). These substances can significantly improve an athlete's physical capabilities, such as strength, endurance, and recovery time, which can lead to better performance and increased chances of winning. This undermines the spirit of fair competition, as other athletes have trained hard without resorting to such enhancements.

Second, many PEDs pose serious health risks. For instance, anabolic steroids can cause liver damage, cardiovascular issues, and hormonal imbalances. Stimulants like amphetamines can lead to heart problems, high blood pressure, and mental health issues. Additionally, PEDs can be addictive, leading to long-term dependency and potential overdose.

Third, doping can have psychological impacts. Athletes might feel pressured to use these substances to stay competitive, even if they do not want to. This can lead to stress, anxiety, and ethical dilemmas, as athletes may feel they must compromise their values to succeed.

Fourth, there is a risk of contamination. Legal medications, dietary supplements, or even food products consumed by athletes can contain banned substances, leading to unintentional doping. This highlights the need for strict monitoring and testing protocols to ensure fairness and safety.

Lastly, doping erodes public trust in sports. When doping scandals occur, it damages the reputation of athletes, teams, and entire sports organizations. It also raises questions about the integrity of competitions and the effectiveness of anti-doping measures.

In conclusion, while doping might seem appealing for short-term gains, its negative consequences far outweigh any benefits, making it a detrimental practice in sports. </answer>

question: how big companies avoid taxes
agent_answer:
<answer>Large companies avoid taxes through various strategies, including:

1. **Offshoring Profits**: By shifting profits to countries with lower tax rates, companies can reduce their overall tax liability. This strategy involves moving intellectual property to subsidiaries in tax havens and charging higher fees to use it.

2. **Accelerated Depreciation**: Companies can accelerate the write-off of capital assets, thereby reducing taxable income. The 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act allowed companies to fully depreciate qualifying investments in the year they were made, saving significant amounts in federal taxes.

3. **Tax Credits**: The U.S. tax code includes numerous tax credits for businesses, such as those for investments in renewable power, clean transportation, and energy security. These credits can significantly reduce a company's tax liability.

4. **Restricted Stock Units (RSUs)**: Companies often use RSUs for employee compensation. Since the tax deduction is taken when the shares vest, rather than when the RSUs are granted, companies can defer tax payments. This strategy is particularly effective if the stock price appreciates significantly.

5. **Use of Tax Havens**: Companies can shift profits to tax havens, where the tax rates are minimal or nonexistent. This strategy has been a significant contributor to tax avoidance, especially for multinational corporations.

6. **Legal Tax Loopholes**: The U.S. tax code is complex and filled with various loopholes that companies can exploit to reduce their tax burden. For instance, the CARES Act of 2020 allowed companies to carry back net operating losses to previous years, further reducing their tax liability.

Despite these strategies, the U.S. government has implemented measures to combat tax avoidance. The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 imposed a 15% minimum income tax on corporations earning at least $1 billion annually and provided substantial tax credits for renewable energy investments. However, the effectiveness of these measures remains to be seen, as corporations continue to find innovative ways to minimize their tax liabilities. </answer>

Some proposed changes are designed specifically to generate more tax revenue from the nation’s largest companies, such as Amazon, Nike, Netflix, HP and FedEx – all examples lawmakers have highlighted as firms that pay relatively modest tax bills despite annual profits in the billions of dollars according to public financial statements.
Accounting professor Scott Dyreng of Duke University’s Fuqua School of Business conducts research on several strategies big corporations use to keep their tax bills low. He explains some of those tactics in this Fuqua Q&A.
Do these companies really pay no income taxes?
We cannot truly know the answer to that question because tax returns are private. So when people say, for example, ‘Amazon paid no taxes,’ they are likely referencing tax cost estimates included in a company’s disclosed financial accounting statements, such as annual 10K filings with the U.S. Securities Exchange Commission (SEC).
Amazon is an example that comes up repeatedly, so I took time to review financial statements from 2012 to 2018, which show Amazon reported $25.4 billion in domestic pretax profits and paid about $2 billion in federal taxes. That’s an 8-percent rate. Although this is a rough calculation, and quite low relative to the official corporate tax rate of 21 percent, it is not negative or zero.
Why do people believe these large companies aren’t paying?
People often look at the pre-tax profits of a company in their SEC filings and compare those figures to the company’s “current provision” for U.S. income taxes.
Every year, many companies report large profits and very low or even negative taxes. For example, Salesforce reported about $2.5 billion in pre-tax U.S. profits in 2021, but reported a current federal tax expense of negative $12 million.

Many companies generate tax credits for investments in research and development or sustainable energy.

question: why did the hippie movement die
agent_answer:
<answer>
The hippie movement declined due to a combination of factors:

1. **Vietnam War**: The war was a significant unifying force for the hippie movement. As the war wound down, the primary rallying point for many hippies diminished, causing a loss of cohesion.

2. **Drug Burnout**: Many hippies, especially those involved in substance use, experienced a decline in creativity and functionality. This was partly due to the shift from more natural substances like marijuana to harder drugs like heroin, which can lead to addiction and impaired cognitive function.

3. **Growing Up and Moving On**: By the early 1970s, many hippies had achieved their initial goals, such as "turning on, tuning in, and dropping out." They started to transition into more conventional roles, including starting families and pursuing careers, thus losing the counterculture's counterclockwise ethos.

4. **Mainstreaming**: Some hippies decided to integrate into mainstream society rather than continue their countercultural lifestyle. They pursued careers in social services, medicine, and other "right livelihood" occupations, carrying some of their ideals forward.

5. **Changing Fashion and Cultural Attitudes**: The novelty of hippie fashion and cultural attitudes diminished over time. The sexual revolution and the rise of dangerous drugs and sexually transmitted diseases like AIDS led to a shift in attitudes toward sex and drugs, making the hippie ideals less appealing.

6. **Environmental Policies and Climate Change**: The 1970s saw the implementation of significant environmental policies, which marked a shift in public discourse and action towards environmental protection. This period also highlighted the potential for lifestyle changes to impact the environment positively, setting the stage for future environmental activism.

These factors collectively contributed to the decline of the hippie movement, transforming its ideals and practices into more mainstream elements of society.

So it makes perfect sense that Hippie fashions, whatever they ended up being, would be a reaction to 50's Eisenhower-era fashions. The best words there are "drab" and "conservative". We are talking very subdued colors, or pastels if you want to be racy. Short buzz-cuts for men, along with fairly well-fitted suits designed to not draw attention to the wearer. Long dresses and shortish hair on women. Popular music came from large band and orchestras.
So it makes perfect sense that their kids fashions would go against all of this. Bright colors. Long hair for everyone. Loose clothing for men, short skirts for women (or going the other way, clothing identical to men's). Music from small (5 or less member) bands.

question: how do diversity and inclusion differ?
agent_answer:
<answer> Diversity and inclusion are often discussed together but have distinct meanings and implications:

Diversity refers to the range of differences that exist within a group or organization, including but not limited to race, ethnicity, gender, age, religion, sexual orientation, and physical ability. It focuses on recognizing and valuing these differences and ensuring that various groups are represented.

Inclusion, on the other hand, is about creating an environment where every individual feels respected, valued, and supported to contribute their full potential. It involves actively engaging with diverse perspectives and ensuring that everyone has equal opportunities to participate and succeed.

The key difference lies in the action taken: diversity is about acknowledging and appreciating differences, while inclusion is about taking steps to ensure those differences are leveraged for positive outcomes. Inclusion goes beyond simply having diverse members; it requires intentional efforts to create a welcoming and supportive atmosphere for all.

Both concepts are crucial for fostering a positive organizational culture and achieving better outcomes. However, they must be addressed separately to fully realize their benefits. </answer>

question: how gender stereotypes harm women
agent_answer:
<answer> Gender stereotypes can significantly harm women by limiting their opportunities, reinforcing harmful behaviors, and affecting mental health. These stereotypes often portray women as nurturing, submissive, and less capable in leadership roles or certain professions. This can lead to unequal treatment in the workplace, such as lower pay for equal work, fewer promotions, and less access to high-level positions. Women may also face pressure to conform to these expectations, which can stifle personal growth and ambition.

Stereotypes about women's capabilities can result in discrimination and bias. For instance, hiring managers might unconsciously favor male candidates over equally qualified female candidates. Additionally, women who defy these stereotypes by excelling in traditionally male-dominated fields may face backlash or be seen as "not feminine enough." 

Moreover, gender stereotypes can contribute to mental health issues. Women may internalize societal expectations that they must be perfect in multiple roles (e.g., mother, wife, employee), leading to stress and anxiety. The pressure to maintain an idealized image of femininity can also contribute to eating disorders and body image issues.

It's important to recognize that while these stereotypes exist, they are not inherent truths about individuals. Efforts to challenge and change these stereotypes are crucial for creating a more equitable society. </answer>

question: why do we need to know our culture
agent_answer:
<answer> Understanding one's culture is essential because it provides a framework for understanding values, beliefs, behaviors, and social norms that shape an individual's identity and interactions with others. Culture influences how we perceive the world, communicate, solve problems, and make decisions. It also plays a crucial role in our emotional well-being and helps us navigate social relationships effectively.

Cultures can vary widely in terms of language, customs, traditions, and historical experiences, which means that knowing one's own culture can help in appreciating diversity and fostering empathy towards others. This understanding can lead to better cross-cultural communication and reduce misunderstandings.

Moreover, recognizing cultural aspects of oneself can enhance self-awareness and self-esteem. It allows individuals to connect with their heritage, which can provide a sense of belonging and continuity. Cultural knowledge also supports personal growth and resilience, as it equips individuals with the tools to adapt to different situations and environments.

On the other hand, being aware of one's culture can also highlight areas where personal biases or prejudices might exist, prompting introspection and the potential for personal development. It can also serve as a foundation for critical thinking and ethical decision-making, as cultural norms often reflect societal values and principles.

In summary, knowing one's culture is important because it shapes identity, enhances communication skills, promotes empathy and understanding, supports personal and emotional well-being, and contributes to ethical and culturally competent behavior. </answer>

Digital marketing helps grow your business in several ways:

1. **Wider Reach and Target Market**: Digital marketing allows businesses to expand their reach globally with minimal additional costs. By setting up campaigns on platforms like Google and social media, businesses can target specific demographics and geographic locations efficiently.

6. **Engagement and Interaction**: Digital platforms enable direct interaction with customers, allowing businesses to gather feedback, address concerns, and build relationships. This engagement fosters loyalty and can lead to repeat business and positive referrals.

Some of the artist’s major influences were Edvard Munch, Henri Toulouse de Lautrec, Paul Cézanne, Henri Rousseau and Georges Braque, who worked with Picasso to found the school of Cubism. Classically trained in the European school, Picasso emerged as a symbolist, drawing on Impressionism through Munch and Post-Impressionism via Lautrec. From Cézanne and Rousseau, he learned about archaic and tribal art, which led him toward Cubism.
Picasso strove to define his place in the history of painting from the outset of his long career. Art historians consider his late works direct dialogues with Old Masters such as Velazquez, Goya and Rembrandt. He lived most of his life in France, so Picasso knew the latest trends and schools of art. Accordingly, he studied Symbolism, which worked to build a visual language of the soul from imagery drawn from mythology and dreams. Picasso also drew on Impressionist Munch to explore the nature of souls. Clearly Lautrec influenced his palette and his choice of subjects – prostitutes and the poor – during his Blue period, so-called because of his blue and gray palette. In fact, much of Picasso’s early work experiments with color – beginning in 1897 in violet and green through the Blue and consequent Rose period and his orange and red palette. This led him to experiment with shape as well, following Cezanne – Post-Impressionism influenced by primitive art – and Rousseau – experiments in Naïve art. Picasso began to use more angular shapes and figures, as well as more color, as he worked toward founding cubism with Braque, where the artist analyzes a subject or shape, disassembles it, then reassembles it in an abstracted form. Working in cubism led Picasso to invent collage and work toward a second form of Cubism (synthetic) where artists worked in mixed media.

For example, they can methodically arrange a series of different-sized sticks in order by length, while younger children approach a similar task in a haphazard way.
These new cognitive skills increase the child’s understanding of the physical world, however according to Piaget, they still cannot think in abstract ways. During middle and late childhood children make strides in several areas of cognitive function including the capacity of working memory, their ability to pay attention, and their use of memory strategies. Both changes in the brain and experience foster these abilities.
Working Memory: The capacity of working memory expands during middle and late childhood, and research has suggested that both an increase in processing speed and the ability to inhibit irrelevant information from entering memory are contributing to the greater efficiency of working memory during this age (de Ribaupierre, 2002). These pieces have a melancholy about them, and are quite somber, featuring scenes of poverty and desolation. What was Picasso’s inspiration to start painting in this way? In the spring of 1901, one of Picasso’s dear friends, a painter and poet named Carlos Casagemas, committed suicide in a cafe in Paris. Picasso was deeply affected by his death, and sank into a depression that lasted several years. Picasso’s journey through his grief and depression is clearly reflected in his “Blue Period.”
In 1904, Picasso moved to Montmartre in Paris, and settled into the community of bohemian artists and creators there. Coming out of his depression over his friend’s death, Picasso moved on from dark and serious subjects in his paintings to more lighthearted compositions featuring harlequins, clowns and carnival performers. His color palette warmed up as well, with his paintings now bathed in reds, oranges, pinks and earth tones. This period would be known as Picasso's “Rose Period” and it lasted until 1906. Olivier would be the first of a long line of women who were muses and lovers to Picasso over the years. This way of breaking down a form to its most basic forms and reconstructing them in an abstracted way is what Picasso is most known for.

question: should schools get involved in cyberbullying
agent_answer:
<answer> Schools should get involved in addressing cyberbullying because it is a significant issue that can have severe impacts on students' mental health and well-being. Cyberbullying can occur outside of school hours but still affect students while they are at school, impacting their ability to learn and socialize. Schools can play a crucial role in creating a safe environment and educating students about the consequences of cyberbullying.

Research has shown that when schools take an active role in preventing and addressing cyberbullying, it can lead to a decrease in incidents. This involvement can include implementing policies, providing education on digital citizenship, and offering support services for both victims and perpetrators. However, there are caveats; schools must ensure that their approach is balanced and does not infringe on students' privacy or free speech rights.

For instance, according to the Cyberbullying Research Center, schools that have strong anti-bullying policies and provide resources for students tend to have lower rates of cyberbullying. These policies often include clear definitions of cyberbullying, procedures for reporting incidents, and consequences for those who engage in such behavior.

On the other hand, some argue that schools should not overly intervene in online behavior that occurs outside of school grounds. They believe that such actions should be handled through parental guidance and community efforts rather than school policies. Nevertheless, given the pervasive nature of technology and its impact on students, schools have a responsibility to create a supportive environment that extends beyond the physical campus.

In conclusion, while schools should be involved in addressing cyberbullying, they need to do so in a way that respects legal boundaries and student rights, focusing on prevention, education, and support. </answer>

Cost-push inflation (e.g. due to rising oil prices) can lead to inflation and lower growth. This is the worst of both worlds and is more difficult to control without leading to lower growth. Coronary Heart Disease (CHD) can significantly impact a person's lifestyle in several ways:

1. **Physical Activity**: CHD often necessitates lifestyle changes, including increasing physical activity. Regular exercise is crucial for managing CHD, but patients may face limitations, particularly in engaging in contact sports or high-intensity activities. For instance, individuals might need to avoid activities that could lead to falls or injuries due to the use of blood thinners.

2. **Diet**: Adopting a heart-healthy diet is essential. Patients are advised to follow diets like the DASH diet, which is rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, and low in saturated fats and sodium. This dietary change can affect food preferences and meal planning, potentially leading to challenges in maintaining a balanced diet.

3. **Weight Management**: Maintaining a healthy weight is critical for managing CHD. Weight loss through diet and exercise can improve heart function and reduce strain on the heart. However, this process can be challenging and requires consistent effort.

4. **Alcohol Consumption**: CHD patients are often advised to limit or avoid alcohol consumption due to its potential to increase blood pressure and interact with medications. This can affect social situations where alcohol is commonly consumed, impacting social life.

5. **Smoking**: Quitting smoking is highly recommended for CHD patients as smoking significantly increases the risk of heart attacks and other complications. The process of quitting can be difficult and may require support from healthcare providers and possibly medications.

6. **Emotional Well-being**: Living with CHD can lead to stress and anxiety. Patients may experience feelings of isolation or fear about future health complications, which can affect their mental health and overall quality of life.

7. **Social Interactions**: CHD can also impact social interactions. For example, individuals might need to be cautious about certain activities, and they may face challenges in sharing their condition with friends and family. This can lead to feelings of stigma or exclusion.

Overall, while CHD can impose significant constraints, adopting a proactive approach to lifestyle changes, such as following a healthy diet, engaging in regular exercise, and adhering to medical advice, can help mitigate these impacts and improve quality of life. Support from family, friends, and healthcare professionals is crucial in navigating these changes effectively.

The good news is that lifestyle changes can make a difference. In a study analyzing over 55,000 people, those with favorable lifestyle habits such as not smoking, not being obese, engaging in regular physical activity, and eating a healthy diet lowered their heart disease risk by nearly 50%.

How can I reduce my risk for diabetes?
Diabetes is a major risk factor for heart disease. Fortunately, lifestyle changes can help. For example, if you have prediabetes, losing at least 7% of body weight and engaging in 150 minutes or more per week of moderate-intensity physical activity has been shown to reduce the risk of progressing to diabetes.
Healthy diets, such as the Mediterranean diet and the DASH diet, and plant-based diets emphasizing foods higher in fiber and omega-3 fatty acids, and lower in glycemic load and saturated fats, are also recommended.
How much exercise do I need?
The Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans from the US Department of Health and Human Services recommend that all adults ages 18 to 64 engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic exercise per week or 75 minutes of vigorous aerobic activity per week — or an equivalent mix of the two. Activities such as brisk walking, running, swimming, biking, and other aerobic exercises are all good options.
As a general rule, being active is better than being sedentary. For example, taking at least 4,400 steps daily is associated with lower risk of death than taking only 2,700 steps per day.
How bad is smoking for my health?
Smokers have a higher heart disease risk than never-smokers, and two to three times the risk of death. The more you smoke, the higher your risk of death.
Quit-smoking medications like varenicline (Chantix) and bupropion (Wellbutrin), and nicotine replacement therapies, are generally safe and can effectively help people quit smoking..

Doc 3(Title: "How CHD Affects One's Social Life - ACHA") I am a glass half full kind of person. Regardless of what I’ve been going through over the years, I’ve learned that there will always be someone enduring even greater struggles. Yes, I have barriers and limitations with my heart defect that affect my social life. For example, if I happen to fall or trip, I have more concerns than others because I am on a blood thinner, which means my bleeding won’t stop easily. I often ponder when precisely the best time is to disclose my heart defect to new friends, it is a tough balance between realizing that it is such a significant part of my life and who I am while also avoiding the “poor me” mentality that can come with the disclosure. But my fellow young adult heart patient peers and I often ask ourselves this question: If it wasn’t for our heart defects, how exactly would our social lives be different? Would we be playing contact sports or having more than two alcoholic beverages when we’re out with friends? For me, the answer is easy. No, it wouldn’t be much different.
Let me address one barrier at a time. First: restrictions on contact sports. Growing up, I was a stereotypical “theater geek”. The closest thing I got to contact sports were dance classes and musical theater choreography, and my motto was often, “I can’t, I have rehearsal.” It was my passion. Even if I could play sports, like soccer or softball, I don’t think I would have. I participated in gym classes in elementary school and had a very understanding gym teacher who allowed me to rest when needed. The backlash came from my peers, who often couldn’t understand why they could not sit down and rest while I could. But there were other times when my close friends ran the last length of our mile run right along side me just so I wouldn’t be alone. It was recommended by my teachers and doctors that I be excused from the more rigorous gym class curriculum in middle and high school, but I still remained active, walking, bike riding, swimming and dancing as often as possible. I’ve met many heart patients who are bothered by not being able to participate in contact sports, but I’ve dedicated my extra-curricular time on other activities that are more heart-friendly and I thoroughly enjoyed.
The second barrier that has had an effect on my social life is going out and having a good time with friends, which is a big part of most young adult lives. I’ve developed the mentality that I can still do this while not jeopardizing my health. Even in college, I preferred attending a movie night with friends than going to a party and I was thankful to find groups who provided my kind of social events. Even though the decision was easy for me, it was more difficult for some of my peers to understand. I’ve been questioned multiple times by friends, been told that, “I have a family member with a heart defect that drinks a lot, why can’t you?” I’ve been told that friends are concerned that I’m not having a good time because I am not drinking as much as they are. I care too much about my heart, effects on medications, and my health to do that to myself, and I’ve learned that my close friends not only don’t question my personal decision not to drink excessively, but support it wholeheartedly.
I have been so grateful over the past 13 years to develop a strong family of fellow heart patients. Thanks to Camp Odayin, a camp for kids with heart conditions, where I began as a camper and now remain involved as a volunteer counselor, I have close friends that share my mindset about our barriers as heart patients. We may not be exactly like other young adults, but we still live full and active lives.

question: how does global warming affect sea life
agent_answer:
<answer> Global warming affects sea life in several ways due to the rising temperatures of the oceans. As the Earth's climate warms, the oceans absorb a significant amount of this heat, leading to increased water temperatures. This warming has multiple impacts on marine ecosystems:

1. **Ocean Acidification**: The absorption of excess carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere leads to ocean acidification. CO2 reacts with seawater to form carbonic acid, reducing the pH of the ocean. This change in chemistry makes it harder for organisms such as corals and mollusks to build their calcium carbonate shells and skeletons, impacting their survival.

2. **Habitat Changes**: Warmer waters can cause shifts in the distribution and abundance of marine species. Many fish and other marine animals migrate towards cooler waters, altering traditional feeding and breeding grounds. This can disrupt food chains and lead to changes in ecosystem dynamics.

3. **Altered Ocean Currents**: Global warming can affect ocean currents, which play a crucial role in regulating temperature and nutrient distribution across different regions. Changes in these currents can impact the availability of nutrients and oxygen, affecting the health and productivity of marine ecosystems.

4. **Increased Sea Level Rise**: As global temperatures rise, glaciers and ice caps melt, contributing to sea level rise. Higher sea levels can lead to coastal flooding and erosion, destroying habitats such as mangroves and coral reefs that serve as nurseries for many marine species.

5. **Heat Stress**: Marine organisms, particularly those at the upper limits of their thermal tolerance, face increased risk of heat stress. This can lead to reduced growth rates, decreased reproductive success, and even mortality in severe cases.

6. **Oxygen Depletion**: Warm water holds less dissolved oxygen than colder water. This, combined with increased metabolic rates of warmer water, can lead to hypoxic (low-oxygen) conditions in the ocean, known as dead zones, where most marine life cannot survive.

These effects are interconnected and can exacerbate each other, leading to more significant disruptions in marine ecosystems. Understanding and addressing these issues is critical for protecting the biodiversity and health of our oceans. </answer>

question: why did people start using money instead of bartering for their wants and needs?

Based on the information provided, here's a summary:

1. **Barter System Limitations**: Bartering directly for goods and services had several limitations. It required a "double coincidence of wants," meaning both parties must want what the other is offering. This made trade inefficient and limited.

2. **Emergence of Money**: Money emerged as a solution to these limitations. It facilitated trade by serving as a medium of exchange, a unit of account, a store of value, and a standard of deferred payment.

3. **Advantages of Money**:
   - **Medium of Exchange**: Money allowed for indirect exchange, reducing the need for a double coincidence of wants.
   - **Unit of Account**: It provided a standardized measure of value, making it easier to compare and evaluate different goods and services.
   - **Store of Value**: Money could be saved and used for future purchases, unlike perishable goods.
   - **Standard of Deferred Payment**: It enabled the concept of lending and borrowing, allowing for economic growth and development.
   - **Portability and Durability**: Unlike perishable goods, money is portable and durable, facilitating long-distance trade.
   - **Political Control**: Governments could control the production and distribution of money, influencing economic policies and social structures.

4. **Historical Context**: The evolution of money from simple objects to coins, paper money, and eventually digital forms reflects humanity's ongoing need for a reliable and efficient means of exchange.

question: how does food bring cultures together
agent_answer:
<answer> Food plays a significant role in bringing cultures together due to its ability to serve as a universal language that transcends cultural, social, and economic barriers. Sharing meals is often a central part of cultural practices and traditions, allowing people from different backgrounds to come together and share experiences. For instance, during festivals and celebrations, food is used to honor cultural heritage and strengthen community bonds.

Culinary exchanges and influences across different regions also help in bridging cultural gaps. As people migrate or travel, they bring their culinary traditions with them, leading to the fusion of flavors and cooking techniques. This exchange of food can lead to the creation of new dishes and the adaptation of existing ones, fostering mutual understanding and appreciation among diverse groups.

Moreover, food can act as a common ground for dialogue and learning about other cultures. Cooking classes, food festivals, and cultural events centered around food provide opportunities for individuals to engage with one another and learn about the significance and preparation methods of various dishes. These interactions can break down stereotypes and promote empathy and respect for cultural differences.

However, it's important to note that while food can bring people together, it can also highlight cultural differences and create challenges. For example, dietary restrictions based on religion, health concerns, or personal beliefs might limit the extent to which certain foods can be shared. Additionally, the commercialization and globalization of certain cuisines can sometimes lead to the loss of traditional cooking methods and ingredients, potentially diminishing the cultural significance of these foods.

In summary, food is a powerful tool for cultural exchange and unity, but its effectiveness depends on how it is used and perceived within different communities. </answer>

question: why did hoverboards fail
agent_answer:
<answer> Hoverboards failed due to a combination of factors including safety concerns, technological limitations, and marketing issues. Firstly, safety was a major issue. Thousands of children were injured by hoverboards, primarily due to falls. These accidents occurred mostly at home and were more common in younger users. The risk of falling was exacerbated by the low center of gravity of hoverboards, requiring a significant amount of core strength to maintain balance. Additionally, the lack of regulation and oversight led to many hoverboards having faulty lithium-ion batteries, which could overheat and catch fire, causing further injuries.

Technologically, the hoverboard concept, as depicted in Back to the Future, promised levitation, but the reality fell short. Early versions, such as those produced by Mattel, were essentially motorized scooters without the ability to float. Even later models that attempted to mimic the floating effect through vibrations and sound effects still failed to deliver the desired experience.

Marketing also played a role. Companies often exaggerated the capabilities of hoverboards, promising more than what was possible with current technology. This mismatch between expectations and reality led to disappointment and a loss of consumer trust. Furthermore, the rapid rise and subsequent decline of hoverboards can be compared to the lifecycle of many fad products, where initial hype leads to overproduction and then a crash when demand cannot be sustained.

In summary, the failure of hoverboards can be attributed to safety hazards, technological limitations, and misleading marketing, all of which contributed to a loss of consumer confidence and interest. </answer>

<information>Doc 1(Title: "Thousands of kids injured by hoverboards in their first 2 ...") Thousands of kids injured by hoverboards in their first 2 years on the market
The hoverboard craze that swept the nation in 2015 and 2016 landed more than 26,000 kids in hospital emergency rooms, according to new research. Millions of the self-balancing scooters were sold before reports of batteries overheating and bursting into flames prompted widespread recalls.
But it turns out that falls — not fires — were by far the most common cause of injuries.
"Hoverboards have a very low center of gravity, increasing the risk of falls," Dr. Robert Glatter, emergency physician at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City, told CBS News. "Riding one safely requires a good amount of core strength to maintain your balance. It often looks a lot easier to ride one than it really is."
The study, published in the journal Pediatrics, analyzed data from across the country regarding injuries from hoverboards in children and adolescents younger than 18 between 2015 — when they were first introduced to the U.S. market — and 2016. During that time, 26,854 hoverboard injuries were treated in U.S. emergency departments.
The highest number of hoverboard injuries occurred in 12-year-old boys. Overall, boys accounted for 52 percent of cases and girls 48 percent.
The wrists were the most commonly injured body part, followed by the forearms and the head.
Fractures were the most common diagnosis, accounting for 40 percent of cases, followed by contusions and strains/sprains.
The study also tracked the number of injuries involving traditional skateboards. During the same two-year time period, skateboard injuries sent 121,398 kids under age 18 to the E.R. Three-quarters of them were boys.
Most patients were treated and released, but 3 percent of those suffering hoverboard or skateboard injuries were admitted to the hospital. Head injuries accounted for 14 percent of hospital admissions related to hoverboards and 35 percent of admissions for skateboard injuries.
While the majority of skateboarding injuries occurred on the street, the researchers found most hoverboard injuries occurred at home.
Glatter, who was not involved in the study, said the risk for injuries is significantly increased when a person is multitasking and therefore distracted while riding a hoverboard.
"I continue to see young teens with head and wrist injuries in the E.R., often the result of being distracted by using a smartphone and listening to music while riding a hoverboard," he said.
In 2016, more than 500,000 hoverboards were recalled after dozens of reports that their lithium-ion batteries had burst into flames. In March 2017, a 2-year-old girl died and two other children were injured in a Pennsylvania house fire that officials said was sparked by a hoverboard battery.
However, the study of 2015-16 incidents identified only three cases of burn injuries in children — none of which were from the toys' malfunctioning batteries.
In two instances, kids were burned when they rode a hoverboard in the kitchen and collided with a pot of boiling water. The other suffered a friction burn after a hoverboard ran over the child's finger.
The American Academy of Pediatrics advises against allowing children under age 16 to operate unlicensed motorized wheeled vehicles. Glatter also says he does not recommend allowing young people to use hoverboards at any age.
"My personal feeling is that they are unsafe, and I would advise parents against allowing their teens and children to ride them," he said. "That said, I would advise caution if you do allow your child to ride one. It's essential that they wear an appropriate and well-fitted helmet, as well as wrist guards with padding to reduce the risk for injury."
Doc 2(Title: "A Brief History of Mattel's Failed Hoverboards") A Brief History of Mattel's Failed Hoverboards
On this 'Back to the Future' day, we revisit Mattel's hoverboard blunders.
As you’ve no doubt heard a thousand times today, in the 1989 movie Back to the Future II, Michael J. Fox’s Marty McFly traveled to October 21st, 2015 (Did you know that is today?). He rode a hoverboard and wore a puffy varsity jacket:
As popularity of the Back to the Future franchise ballooned, the hoverboard, a neon, flying skateboard-without-wheels that looks like a pastel version of Eddie Van Halen’s guitar, became an object of desire. Toy company Mattel seized on that collective want and made its own “hoverboard” in 1989, the year of Back to the Future II’s release.
Except, as we all know now, the toy seemed like cruel joke. Given that the first launch of Mattel’s hoverboard occurred in 1989, actual floatation was never going to happen, but the lack of technology did not prevent Mattel from marketing the product with a shameful level of deceit.
Watch Mattel’s first Hoverboard commercial to see why:
While the colors were “totally rad,” what Mattel actually produced was a cumbersome looking heap of plastic that appeared to float on TV. It is a technicolor scooter with handlebars only a poser would use. It doesn’t even have wheels, so it makes one wonder how the thing actually moved. It didn’t, of course.
The dishonest commercial and the toy it hawked roused a backlash among consumers, and it wasn’t until 2012 that Mattel decided to trot out the hoverboard idea again.
Except the rebooted toy landed with a resounding thud in that year, even after a decent amount of press and hype got the sci-fi rank and file all worked up. It didn’t float, either. It does offer speaker that emits a “whooshing” sound effect, which is what the hoverboard might sound like if it was hovering.
Unsurprisingly, there weren’t many positive reviews of the 2012 hoverboard. In fact, some takes on the toy are scathing.
Bob Gale, Back to the Future’s screenwriter, had supported Mattel’s efforts in 2012, but issued a cutting statement on the product once he actually saw it that year. He wasn’t particularly happy about the hoverboard’s $120 price tag, either.
“This product, at this price, falls short of the top-notch standards that you and I have come to expect for something that carries the Back To The Future brand,” he writes. “The plastic stand is poorly designed and damn near impossible to make work. And although it was indicated that the board would somehow glide across certain smooth surfaces (like carpet), mine certainly didn’t.”
The shade thrown at Mattel, especially from the guy who wrote Back to the Future seems warranted, given that all consumers wanted was something that “will gently glide over most level surfaces,” as the toy’s listing on Mattel’s website boasted.
This is kind of funny, given that most efforts to produce an actual, real life hoverboard have proven the task to be nearly impossible and astronomically expensive.

Abstract
This theoretical paper was undertaken to ascertain the causes of poor service delivery and to establish if outsourcing of public service delivery could be used to improve local Authority services. It interrogated and critiqued documents on what other researchers in their different contexts had established in view of the feasibility of outsourcing as a strategy to improve service delivery. It emerged in this study that political interference, lack of citizen participation. lack of funds and corruption were the main causes of poor service delivery in local authorities. Therefore, outsourcing was seen to bring quality and affordable services for the public while costs savings and emergence of hidden costs were the financial implications unveiled for the local authorities (LAs). Social costs, accountability for public service delivery and quality shading were cited to be the outsourcing challenges. It also emerged in this study that outsourcing can increase service quality and provide affordable services for the public. Taking into account the information that was accumulated and examined, the researchers came to the conclusion that the current services being offered by local authorities are very poor and this is attributed to many causes such as political interference, lack of citizen participation, lack of funds and corruption. The study therefore, concludes that outsourcing could be a feasible option to use to improve service delivery by local authorities.

This mismatch between expectations and reality led to disappointment and a loss of consumer trust. Furthermore, the rapid rise and subsequent decline of hoverboards can be compared to the lifecycle of many fad products, where initial hype leads to overproduction and then a crash when demand cannot be sustained.

In summary, the failure of hoverboards can be attributed to safety hazards, technological limitations, and misleading marketing, all of which contributed to a loss of consumer confidence and interest. </answer>

question: how does police corruption affect the public
agent_answer:
<answer> Police corruption can have significant negative impacts on the public. It undermines public trust in law enforcement, distorts the fairness of justice, and can lead to increased crime. Because police officers are supposed to uphold the law and protect citizens, their involvement in criminal activities erodes the public's confidence in these institutions. This loss of trust can make it harder for law enforcement to carry out its duties effectively.

Corruption among police officers can also result in biased enforcement of laws, where certain groups are disproportionately targeted or protected. This can lead to social unrest and exacerbate existing tensions between different communities. Moreover, corrupt practices often involve the abuse of power and resources, leading to misallocation of funds meant for community safety and other public services.

The impact of police corruption extends beyond individual cases; it can create a systemic problem that affects the entire legal system. This can lead to wrongful convictions, as innocent individuals may be wrongly accused or framed due to the manipulation of evidence or testimony. Additionally, corruption can result in the protection of criminals, thereby failing to provide justice to victims and their families.

On a broader societal level, police corruption can contribute to a climate of impunity, where lawbreakers believe they can get away with misconduct. This can further discourage reporting of crimes and hinder efforts to combat criminal activities effectively. The overall effect is a breakdown in social order and a reduction in public safety.

However, it is important to note that not all instances of misconduct within law enforcement constitute corruption. Factors such as poor training, inadequate supervision, and stressful working conditions can also contribute to unethical behavior. Therefore, addressing police corruption requires a comprehensive approach that includes improving training, enhancing oversight mechanisms, and fostering a culture of accountability and integrity within law enforcement agencies.</answer>

question: why is there no long-run trade-off between unemployment and inflation?
agent_answer:
<answer> The concept that there is no long-run trade-off between unemployment and inflation is supported by the theory known as the Non-Accelerating Inflation Rate of Unemployment (NAIRU). NAIRU suggests that there is a natural level of unemployment where the economy operates without causing inflationary pressures in the long run. This idea contrasts with the short-term Phillips Curve, which posits a trade-off between unemployment and inflation.

According to the NAIRU theory, when unemployment falls below its natural rate, firms face increased competition for labor, driving up wages and, consequently, prices. However, if unemployment rises above the natural rate, firms face less competition for workers, leading to lower wage demands and stable prices. Thus, the relationship between unemployment and inflation does not persist in the long term; rather, it stabilizes around the NAIRU.

This concept is supported by empirical evidence and economic models, but it's important to note that the exact level of NAIRU can vary over time due to changes in technology, demographics, and other factors. Additionally, some economists argue that the natural rate of unemployment can shift over time, complicating the relationship further.

In summary, while there might be a short-term trade-off between unemployment and inflation, the long-run trade-off is minimal due to the stabilizing effect of the NAIRU. </answer>
